thread.title: Westpac pulls out of funding payday lenders
thread.title_full: Westpac pulls out of funding payday lenders

author: Clancy Yeates and Shaun Drummond
title: Westpac pulls out of funding payday lenders
text:
Westpac is pulling the plug on financing payday lenders.
Westpac will no longer finance payday lenders, a move that will force companies including Cash Converters and Money3 to obtain some of their funding elsewhere.
After a review of its involvement in payday lending, which has this year come under fire from the corporate watchdog, the bank on Tuesday said it had made a "commercial decision" to cut ties with the industry.
"Westpac can confirm today that after careful consideration, we have made the commercial decision to exit customers who provide payday lending products and will no longer support new customers where we are aware that they provide payday lending products," a spokeswoman said.
Payday lending refers to small consumer loans of a couple of thousand dollars or less, often used to cover household expenses, which attract very high interest rates.
Advertisement Cash Converters and Money3, the two biggest lenders in the industry, will both be affected by the move and their shares fell heavily on Tuesday.
Cash Converters shares dropped 8.7 per cent to 58¢, while Money3 shares fell 7.6 per cent to $1.10.
A Westpac spokeswoman said the bank was working with its affected customers as they looked to find alternative banking services.
"We will honour existing contractual obligations as they manage this transition," she said.
Money3 acting chief executive Scott Baldwin said it had a debt facility with Westpac that had been drawn down by $10 million, and it had the capacity to repay this loan with existing cashflows.
He said it also had a separate $30 million corporate bond facility that would not be affected by Westpac's decision to pull out of the sector.
"Money3 expects to announce a facility in due course that will ensure business growth is not limited by access to funding," Mr Baldwin said in a statement to the Australian Securities Exchange.
He said the company not yet received a notice in writing from Westpac but he had called the bank earlier today to say it was releasing a statement to the market based on Westpac's comments because investors have been asking whether the rumours about its plans were true.
Mr Baldwin argued a car finance facility from Westpac – which it has only provided Money3 for the past 12 months – was not used for payday loans and Westpac had made its decision based on a small number of short-term loans Money3 makes.
"The largest part of our business is now auto loans," he said. "Money 3 doesn't offer a payday loan. We don't offer a loan where that loan is repaid at your next pay. We offer longer-term loans."
Cash Converters said they had not yet received notification from Westpac and would release a statement when they do.
Its latest accounts from the December half said it had a $70 million debt facility with Westpac that had been drawn to $56.9 million at December 31 2014.
Payday lending has long been criticised by consumer groups, and this year the Australian Securities and Investments Commission flagged concerns that some in the industry were not complying with laws designed to protect consumers from predatory behaviour by lenders.
A review of customer files found that two-thirds of borrowers had either taken out two or more payday loans in the last 90 days, or they were in default on a small amount loan.Until now, Westpac's position to fund payday lenders stood in contrast to rival National Australia Bank, which refused to fund the sector.
Meanwhile, there were also reports on Tuesday that Westpac, NAB, ANZ Bank and Commonwealth Bank may have loan exposure of about NZ$300 million ($271 million) to struggling New Zealand coal miner Solid Energy.
Prime Minister John Key this week said the government-owned miner was in a "precarious" position and the government was working out the next steps with the miner's lenders.
